data:
A theme in Nextra works like a layout, that will be rendered as a wrapper for
all pages. This docs will walk you through the process of creating a custom
theme.Optionally, you can deploy an example and build further on it by following the
below steps:
data.configure-nextra-to-use-the-theme#Config:
First, you need to tell Nextra to use your custom theme file instead of official
ones. In your Next.js config, you can pass the path to your theme file to the
Nextra plugin:
data.create-a-basic-theme#Create a Basic Them:
You can now start working on your theme! In your root directory, create the
corresponding theme.tsx file with basic content:

It accepts a children prop, which is the MDX content of the current page, and
wraps some other elements around the content. After creating the theme, you can
simply add a MDX file as pages/index.mdx and see the result:



Inside your theme layout, you can use CSS imports or other ways to style it.
Next.js hooks such as useRouter, Head are also available.
data.render-metadata-for-the-active-page#Rend:
Other than children, some other useful props are passed to the theme layout
too. With the pageOpts props, the theme can access the page‚Äôs meta
information.For example, let‚Äôs implement these features:
Render the page title in <title>
Show a simple table of contents
Add a meta tag for og:image via the front matter
data.use-page-map-of-the-entire-site#Use Page:
Now, if you want to render something like a sidebar or a navigation bar, which
relies on information of not only the current page but also other pages, you can
use the pageMap value.For example, we can render a simple navigation list with all the pages in the
top level:

There are other item kinds such as Folder (for directories) and Meta (for
_meta.json files). All the items are typed so you can easily know the
properties.
data.advanced-usage#Advanced Usage: Docs for advanced usage are under construction.

data:
In Nextra, the site and page structure can be configured via the co-located
_meta.json files. In the docs theme, there are some extra options available to
customize it further.Those configurations affect the overall layout of the theme, especially the
navigation bar and the sidebar.
Read more about Nextra's _meta.json files
here.
data.pages#Pages:
The title and order of a page shown in the sidebar should be configured in the
_meta.json file as key-value pairs. For example, if you have the following
file structure:











You can define how the pages are shown in the sidebar via the _meta.json file:


If any routes are not listed in the _meta.json file, they will be appended
to the end of the sidebar and sorted alphabetically, and the title will be
formatted with Title.
data.folders#Folders:
Folders can be configured in the same way as pages. For example:



















The top-level _meta.json file contains the meta information for the top-level
pages and folders:

And the nested _meta.json file contains the meta information for pages in the
same folder:

This way, information for pages are grouped together in directories. You can
move directories around without having to change the _meta.json file.
data.folders-with-index-page#Folders with Ind:
What if I want to have a folder with an index page? We can add a MDX page with
the same name and in the same directory as the folder. Let's say we want to add
/fruits route in the example above, we can create a fruits.mdx file in
pages:





















Then Nextra knows that the fruits key in _meta.json defines a folder with an
index page. If you click that folder in the sidebar, it will open the folder and
show you the fruits.mdx page at the same time.
data.external-links#External Links:
You can add external links to the sidebar by adding an item with href in
_meta.json:

To always open the link in a new tab, enable the "newWindow": true option:


You can use this option to link to relative internal links too.
data.hidden-routes#Hidden Routes:
By default, all MDX routes in the filesystem will be shown on the sidebar. But
you can hide a specific pages or folders by using the "display": "hidden"
configuration:

The page will still be accessible via the /contact URL, but it will not be
shown in the sidebar.
data.sub-docs#Sub Docs:
By defining a top-level page or folder as "type": "page", it will be shown as
a special page on the navigation bar, instead of the sidebar. With this feature,
you can have multiple "sub docs", and special pages or links such as "Contact
Us" that are always visible.For example, you can have 2 docs folders frameworks and fruits in your
project:























In your top-level _meta.json file, you can set everything as a page, instead
of a normal sidebar item:

And it will look like this:


Live example on StackBlitz
‚Üó
(opens in a new tab)
You can also hide links like Home from the navbar with the
"display": "hidden" option.
data.menus#Menus:
You can also add menus to the navbar using "type": "menu" and the "items"
option:


Live example on StackBlitz
‚Üó
(opens in a new tab)
data.links#Links:
Same as the External Links option, you can have external
links in the navbar too:
data.fallbacks#Fallbacks:
In the Sub Docs example above, we have to define the
"type": "page" option for every page. To make it easier, you can use the "*"
key to define the fallback configuration for all items in this folder:

They are equivalent where all items have "type": "page" set.
data.separators#Separators:
You can use a "placeholder" item with "type": "separator" to create a
separator line between items in the sidebar:


Together with the
sidebar.titleComponent theme
option, you can customize the look of titles and separator lines in the
sidebar.
data.theme-components#Theme Components:
You can configure the theme for each page using the "theme" option. For
example, you can disable or enable specific components for specific pages:

This option will be inherited by all child pages if set to a folder.
data.layouts#Layouts:
By default, each page has "layout": "default" in their theme config, which is
the default behavior.
data.full-layout#Full Layout:
You might want to render some page with the full container width and height, but
keep all the other styles. You can use the "full" layout to do that:
data.typesetting#Typesetting:
The "typesetting" option controls typesetting details like font features,
heading styles and components like li and code. There are "default" and
"article" typesettings available in the docs theme.The default one is suitable for most cases like documentation, but you can use
the "article" typesetting to make it look like an elegant article page:

data: Nextra Docs Theme is a theme that includes almost everything you need to build a modern documentation website. It includes a top navigation bar, a search bar, a pages sidebar, a TOC sidebar, and other built-in components.This website itself is built with the Nextra Docs Theme.
data.deploy-to-vercel#Deploy to Vercel:
You can start by creating your own Nextra site and deploying to Vercel by clicking the link:

Vercel will fork the Nextra Docs template and deploy the site for you. Once done, every commit in the repository will be deployed automatically.
data.fork-the-template#Fork the Template: You can also manually fork the template repository.
data.install#Install:
To create a Nextra Docs site manually, you have to install Next.js, React, Nextra, and Nextra Docs Theme. In your project directory, run the following command to install the dependencies:

install nextra and nextra-theme-docs as the add-ons.
data.add-nextjs-config#Add Next.js Config:
Create the following next.config.js file in your project‚Äôs root directory:

data.create-docs-theme-config#Create Docs The:

If the documentation is inside a monorepo, a subfolder, or a different branch of

useNextSeoProps function returns the props that will be passed to the
Next SEO component.It is also a hook, so you can use APIs like useRouter inside to return values

data.project-link#Project Link:
Show a button that links to your project‚Äôs homepage on the navbar. By default,
it links to Nextra‚Äôs GitHub repository.

You can configure project.link and project.icon to customize the project
link, for example make it link to your GitLab repository:

You can configure chat.link and chat.icon to customize the chat link, for

to learn how to add custom menus or links to the navbar.
data.banner#Banner:
Show a banner on the top of the website. It can be used to show a warning or a
notice.
data.banner-key#Banner key:
A banner can be dismissed. By default banner.key will be "nextra-banner" and
it‚Äôs used by
localStorage
to keep the banner state (dismissed or not) on the client.If you have updated your banner text, you should change the key to make sure the
banner is shown again. The best practice is to always use a descriptive key for
the current text, for example:
data.menu-collapse-level#Menu Collapse Level:
By default, the sidebar menu is collapsed at level 2. You can change it by
setting sidebar.defaultMenuCollapseLevel to a different number. For example,
when set to 1, every folder will be collapsed by default and when set to
Infinity, all nested folders will be expanded by default.If sidebar.autoCollapse is set to true, then all folders that do not contain
an active/focused route will automatically collapse up to the level set by
sidebar.defaultMenuCollapseLevel. e.g. if defaultMenuCollapseLevel is 2,
then top-level folders will not auto-collapse.
data.customize-sidebar-content#Customize side:
Together with the Separators
item, you can customize how the sidebar content is rendered by using the
sidebar.titleComponent option:

data.mdx-components#MDX Components:
Provide custom MDX components to
render the content. For example, you can use a custom pre component to render
code blocks.
data.writing-direction#Writing Direction: The default writing direction of the website.
data.main-content#Main Content:
Render top and/or bottom content of main area of the page. It can be used to
render a comment section, a newsletter form, or any other type of content.
data.table-of-contents#Table of Contents:
Show a table of contents on the right side of the page. It‚Äôs useful for
navigating between headings.
data.floating-toc#Floating TOC:
toc.float is enabled by default. When enabled, the TOC will be displayed on
the right side of the page and it will be sticky when scrolling. If it‚Äôs
disabled, the TOC will be displayed directly on the page sidebar.
data.edit-link#Edit Link:
Show an ‚ÄúEdit this page‚Äù link on the page that points to the file URL on GitHub
(or other places).
data.feedback-link#Feedback Link:
The built-in feedback link provides a way for users to submit feedback about the
documentation. By default, it‚Äôs a link that points to the issue creation form of
the docs repository, with the current website title prefilled:
example.

To disable it, you can set feedback.content to null.
data.navigation#Navigation:
Show previous and next page links on the bottom of the content. It‚Äôs useful for
navigating between pages.





The above is also equivalent to navigation: true.
data.last-updated-date#Last Updated Date:
Show the last updated date of each page. It‚Äôs useful for showing the freshness
of the content.
data.footer#Footer:
The footer area of the website. You can either specify some content for the
default footer, or fully customize it with a custom component.
data.copyright-information#Copyright informat:
You can add some simple content, such as copyright information to the default
footer:

data.favicon-glyph-experimental#Favicon Glyph:
This isn‚Äôt supported by all browsers, but it‚Äôs a nice way to customize the
favicon of the website simply by using an emoji or character.

data.static-image#Static Image:
This feature is enabled via staticImage: true in the Nextra config by
default.
Nextra supports automatically optimizing your static image imports with the
Markdown syntax. You do not need to specify the width and height of the image,
just use the ![]() Markdown syntax:

path, if you don't want to host it via public.
With Next.js Image, there will be no layout shift, and a beautiful blurry

Nextra uses KaTeX to render LaTeX expressions directly in MDX.
To enable LaTeX support, you must enable the latex option in your next.config.js file:

When enabled, KaTeX‚Äôs CSS and fonts will be automatically included in your site, and you can start writing math expressions in your MDX files. Using LaTeX within MDX is as simple as wrapping your expression in $ or $$.
data.example#Example:
For example, the following Markdown code:

will be rendered as:
The Pythagorean equation: .
You can still use Markdown and MDX syntax in the same line as your LaTeX expression.
If you want to display $ in your content instead of rendering it as an
equation, you can escape it with a backslash (\). For example \$e = mc^2\$
will be rendered as $e = mc^2$.

data:
Make beautiful websites with Next.js & MDX.

Simple, powerful and flexible site generation framework with everything you love from Next.js.


Get started ‚Üí













Full-power documentation in minutes.




Links and images are always optimized.

Nextra automatically converts Markdown links and images to use Next.js Link and Next.js Image when possible. No slow navigation or layout shift.
































Advanced syntax highlighting solution.

Performant and reliable build-time syntax highlighting powered by Shiki.



I18n as easy as creating new files.

Name your page files with locales suffixed, Nextra and Next.js will do the rest for you.









MDX 2 lets you use Components inside Markdown, with huge performance boost since v1.





Dark mode included.




Full-text search, zero-config needed.

Nextra indexes your content automatically at build-time and performs incredibly fast full-text search via FlexSearch.














Organize pages intuitively, with file-system routing from Next.js.



A11y as a top priority.

Nextra respects system options such as Increase Contrast and Reduce Motion.



Hybrid rendering, next generation.

You can leverage the hybrid rendering power from Next.js with your Markdown content including SSG, SSR, and ISR.



And more...

SEO / RTL Layout / Pluggable Themes / Built-in Components / Last Git Edit Time / Multi-Docs...A lot of new possibilities to be explored.
